awd_titl_txt: Floquet Theory for Stochastic Temporal Networks and Optimization Theory for the Design of Schedules for COVID-19
awd_abstract_narration:
No problem facing humanity is more severe and more urgent than COVID-19, and the shelter-in-place approach to social distancing has decimated the U.S. economy. COVID-19 social distancing may be required for a long period for a multitude of reasons including the uncertainty of the effectiveness of vaccines on emerging strains. Therefore, it is desired to identify mathematically principled solutions that strike an optimal balance between productivity and risk to infection through developing a “science and engineering for social distancing”. Thus motivated, the PIs will develop (1) novel mathematical theory to better and more rigorously understand epidemic spreading on social-contact networks that undergo weekly and/or daily cycles; and (2) optimization theory to design realistic social-contact networks (e.g., using curfews for community and course scheduling for academic institutions) that both mitigate pandemics and allow an acceptable level of social/economic activity. These techniques will be applied to social-network datasets related to COVID-19 to validate theory and obtain practical knowledge. These mathematical and computational tools and related datasets will support policy makers for educational institutions, large companies, and governing bodies as they manage the economic and health impacts of COVID-19 as well as future pandemics. 

The first goal of the project is to extend Floquet theory of ordinary differential equations to (a) characterize epidemic spreading on social-contact networks that are stochastic, time-varying, and periodic; (b) identify and analyze novel behaviors for disease dynamics that arise because the social-network’s periodicity and the disease progression change at similar time scales; and (c) study the effects of network structures that contribute to disease localization (e.g., in hub nodes and communities in the network). These questions remain underexplored for dynamically changing networks. The second goal of the project is to develop network optimization theory to design mathematically principled social-distancing protocols that can both suppress COVID-19 spreading and also maintain an acceptable level of economic and social activity. Specifically, network perturbation and optimization techniques for Floquet decompositions will be developed, and then they will be combined with non-convex optimization algorithms. To date, mathematical or even computational foundations for social-contact engineering in dynamically changing contact networks due to human activity are lacking. Finally, these techniques will be applied to social-network datasets related to COVID-19 which provide summarized and anonymized movements of individuals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many social and biological networks periodically change over time with daily, weekly, and other cycles. In this project, we developed novel mathematical theory and scientific knowledge to obtain a deeper and more rigorous understanding of epidemic spreading on temporal (i.e., time-varying) contact networks undergoing weekly and/or daily cycles; the obtained results are expected to design realistic social contacts that both mitigate pandemics and allow some human mobility. We formulated and analyzed susceptible-infectious-susceptible (SIS) epidemic models over temporal networks with periodic schedules by assuming that the dynamics of the network are a cycle of alternately used contact patterns, each with a given duration (called periodically switching temporal networks). With this formalism, we discovered Parrondo's paradox behavior in epidemic dynamics. In other words, the periodic alternation of two static networks, each of which sustains epidemic spreading, paradoxically results in suppression of epidemic spreading (i.e., with the number of infectious nodes exponentially decaying over time). We found community structure to play an important role in shaping this phenomenon; the phenomenon occurs more often when the number of communities is small. We also developed perturbation theory to account for this paradoxical phenomenon. Finally, we associated the determinant of epidemic dynamics in switching temporal networks with Floquet theory. Other achievements include formulation and analysis of the dynamics of competition between two types (e.g., genotypes, opinions) on the same type of periodically switching temporal networks. We showed that, on periodically switching networks, the more dominant type is not as likely to propagate as in the case of static networks when the network is small. This result gives insights into epidemic dynamics (which is spreading of one type) on periodically switching networks. Altogether, the research outcomes of this project are expected to impact on network science, mathematical biology, epidemiology, applied mathematics, and computer science, among other research fields.


We trained an applied mathematics PhD student in Department of Mathematics at University at Buffalo in this project. Owing to this project, she has developed both mathematical and computational skills related to epidemic modeling, network modeling, and data science, as well as research communication skills through conference and other presentations. These acquired skills and achievements should be useful for her to be employable in both academic and industrial markets after the project. In the courses related to network science (MTH 563: Stochastic Processes on Networks), Dr. Masuda introduced outcomes of this project, such as switching temporal networks and epidemic dynamics on them. We provided on Github codebase for the main and other research outcomes.
